title: The RealEstateCore Ontology

author: Karl Hammar, School of Engineering, Jönköping University

segmentation: I am here to talk about the real estate Core Ontology project and I'm actually like the previous speaker not going to talk so much about the ontology or the domain itself.
Becausw, if you're interested in that, the ontology is freely licensed, free to download and look at and play around with, and the paper covers some of the design choices in it.
So the emphasis on this talk will rather be on the development process.
Is the motivations for this project ongoing work and some lessons learned from it.
So this.
Project concerns how to model real estate owner data integration.
And real estate owners.
They typically have grown through acquisition Becausw it's there's a limited number.

There is a limited amount of land to build on, so you typically when you grow such a company, you purchase buildings that already exist, and those buildings typically come with built-in systems of various kinds, and therefore you have a substantial data and systems integration.
Challenge.
Right?
OK.
So that's a need for them to integrate data across things that they've acquired.
They also have a need of enabling ecosystems.
By this I mean that oftentimes they use sub suppliers, facility management companies, waste management companies.
People who the security stuff you name it.
We want to head into, go into the house and do something there and do something.
Know something about the building and they.

Typically don't have those on board themselves, so they need to provide an interface for them to access the parts of the digital building that are needed to do that task, and you can't do that with 150 APIs 'cause you have 150 buildings, you need to standardize somehow in order to get some scale on that.

There's of course some staining sustainability challenges in terms of the energy efficiency, which is very much about a driver these days where you may want to do analytics on the building to ensure that you are running the heating and cooling systems up North and Sweden.
It's typically heating systems.

I understand in other countries typically cooling systems were running them in as efficient way as possible, and again you can't have one API per building as is traditionally the case when you require these buildings, you need to do some data integration.
There's also analysis challenges regarding how to invest in the buildings and how to measure the utilization of the buildings.
Who is it moving around?
Where in the buildings are the conference rooms used?
Well?
If it's a commercial building with stores in them, how are people moving around in those stores, etc.
And relating to that, the support of tenants and surrounding this abilities.
So there's an interesting sort of interface between the tenant and the real estate Holder in terms of who owns that data about what goes on in the building.
And can we provide services to the tenants to enable them to control their environment in the building?
Or in the case of this store that I mentioned to know about where people are moving in the store right?
And sometimes the sensors aren't owned by the tenant, but actually by the.
Real estate owner.
And so we need to provide some interoperability for people there and regarding municipalities typical use case there would be.
You are running a conference venue and all of a sudden your conference ends and you know 500 people are heading out the doors.
Well, you may want to tell to sort of the smart city that.
OK, perhaps you should bring around some transportation options here.
You want to communicate with surrounding municipality or if you're optimizing heating cooling on sort of a district level, that's also the sort of thing you might want to do.
In conjunction with the municipality around you, and of course there's a bit of brand building in this as well.

These companies that I'm about to present are sort of the leaders of their field and they want to of course look good in a sense to show that they are technically involved in sharing with the community.
So these are some of the drivers.
For this work.
Here are the consortium founders and I should say the top three logos on the right.
There are substantial real estate holders.
Have also Conan is number one in Sweden and #5 in Europe.

I believe in terms of valuation of their properties so there at about 2.7 million square meters valued at well, we're talking in the 10s of millions of euros, billions of euros I came across is number 2 in Sweden.
They own all the University campuses in Sweden pretty much.
So we have three real estate companies representing violence, commercial academic houses, academic Vietnamese, residential, so apartments.
We have Eden, which is a technology development company or software development company.
That's a spinoff of Auto Corona or developing a system based on this, and we have Research Institute rise and then we have my University down in the bottom there.
How have?
We got about this.
Well, it's thoroughly a collaboration project between these industry partners and academia and the Research Institute.
And that means that sometimes one needs to take a step back and sort of drop the academic pretensions a little bit.
And and go for what works.
So we've had to apply a product perspective and minimum viable product perspective throughout, and the goal here is to get this into the hands of developers as soon as possible.
So iterate early, trade off and break things, but not break things badly because they're actually running buildings across the country on this right.
So we build we deploy.
We figure out what's not working, we iterate.

And when we have a choice between usability and applicability on some sense and sort of expressiveness or generalizability or completeness on the other, we always go with what the developers want, which is usability and applicability.
And I realize that may not be sort of what an ontologist would prefer, but the ontologists are not the users of this software developers are.
We try to minimize external dependencies, right?

And the reason why we do that is that these systems and these buildings typically have a lifespan measured in decades and we cannot allow link rot and dependencies on resources that we do not control to interfere with.
With this in 15 years time, right?
So when we need to reuse other things, which there is a good reason to do.
Oftentimes we will clone those things, either the structure or the full sort of axioms and everything, including our eyes, which is sort of.
Not a good code smell, but we do it all the same because it works.
Anyone can say anything about anything?

Of course we try to map and align to existing standards whenever possible, but we do that in a sort of non invasive way where we don't depend on these alignments, but rather provide them as optional for people who need them.

The method is largely influenced by the extreme design method, which is something that's I don't know 15 years old or something by now, and from the neon project that emphasizes modularity of development, emphasizes pair or group development.
In our case, it's groups.
Typically an emphasizes the use of competency questions 2 for requirements management.
An modularity is also useful in our case becausw, even though we're developing one ontology.
It may be that the different real estate real estate owners need to customize that right, and for instance, the types of rooms that are needed.
If your University like academic, who's leaving universities are different compared to if you are a hospital or if you are a residential real estate holders.
So you can plug in and out these modules a little bit or extend upon them while keeping the main structure.
I said I wouldn't go into the the in depth about the ontology so I won't do that, but this is an overview of the modules.
Full Ontology includes all of the modules that we have available.
There is a metadata module which basically brings in Dublin Core and some annotations to allow us to annotate the rest.
There's a core module which contains the concepts that are share.
Right across modules and we're not very sort of principles regarding this, so when we see something show up in multiple places, we move it into the core.
That's good enough, right?
Agents obviously concerned concerns people and organizations that is, as of yet relatively shallow building that contains things like the part hood of a building.
So basically what you'd find in a BIM system, the floors, the rooms, their physical properties of the building, and the relations there.
Device that is what we mountain building.
So sensors and actuators typically and a little bit about the observations that these can make and so forth.
Leases that's supposed to cover and represents.

That's also comparatively shallow at the moment, but that's supposed to represent the fact that we do lease these buildings, or part of them, and we need to recover somehow the contractual obligations on the contractual parties and so forth, so this is being worked on and top level classes and properties there.
And you'll notice, for instance, that quantity kind is something you may recollect from QUDTI believe.
You see Geo geometry down there that's from Geo Sparkle.
So we're reusing good stuff when we find it, but we clone it shamelessly.
And of course we had an annotation saying where we got it from, 'cause that's the honest way.
Um?
Here is another illustration, also in the paper about some of the core concepts.
Annual note.
There there's sensor and actuator and observation and devices and so forth.

So a lot of the stuff a lot of the use cases so far have been about this sort of stuff that you would typically find in SSN so so, so I'm grateful that the next speaker will speak about SSN, so so you may ask, why aren't we just using Amazon?
So so as it's and I'll touch upon that if I have time later on.
But these are sort of the core things at the moment, right?
So some developmental tradeoffs and challenges we've faced, right?
The modularize ability thing allows customization, which is good, but it does complicate ecosystem development because what we're doing with this is we figured having ontology is not enough.
Having ontologies useful, but we also need our APIs for sending data expressed per that ontology, so we need rest APIs.
We need streaming data APIs, and if we're saying that there is such a thing.
Real Estate core ontology.
You can use it here right and we're saying that we're building APIs that adhere to that.
What does that mean?
If that month ontology can be adjusted and modularized, right?
How can I express that to a software developer who don't know what's the actual configuration of the ontology on the other end?

So what we're working on there is API auto generation and we're about halfway through to on that, so from the album ontology generate Open API spec from Open API spec, you have your REST API definitions and you can generate client server stubs and in that generator we're probably going to add also some some metadata endpoint saying.
Basically this is the configuration, that of this rest endpoint, or rather the ontology that was used to generate this rest endpoints.
So that's what we're working on right now, and hopefully we'll see if that's expressive and powerful enough, we're working on it.
Work in progress.
Another thing which is for our users.
They typically want when they're looking at the documentation, the visualization they want, UML diagrams or ER diagrams or schema diagrams.
Sort of conceptual diagrams on screen, right?

If you're going to render an ontology in such a way, you typically want to have Singleton domains and ranges for your properties, because otherwise properties will show up in multiple places, and it will be unclear what they mean, right?
You typically want one node, another node, and a connection between it.
And that connection has one domain in one range, whether that be our DFS domain, arrange or restrictions.
It's the same really.
So the problem with that is that when we're doing APIs that send out Jason, specifically Jason LD, you would often want to reuse your fields, right?
You would want the field to be named something like, has location or has sensor or something, right?
Not room has sense or right, but has sensor.

And if you're generating those fields from the ontology, that becomes a bit of a conceptual mismatch, so we're trying to figure out how to handle that well, and scope domains are probably a way of going about that and so relaxing this restriction on single domain single range a little bit there.
And then the foundational ontologies we don't use foundation of ontologies because we don't want to bring in foundational concepts that are cognitively irrelevant to our software developer users.
We don't want them to start thinking about, you know foundation or bfor Dulce or whatever concepts when they're trying to model.
That building has sensors in it.
At the same time, we have real.
Is that we are getting these cognitive clustering issues.
We're getting along class of things or long list of classes.
And they need to be grouped somehow, so we're going to have to figure that out.
Yet we haven't.
We don't know how to do that just yet.
We're working on it.

Right, this is 1 system that reference system that actually is being run at both secure and the Eden Proptech OS platform where consuming from underlying systems using the real estate core vocabulary.
That's what the little blue thing there is.
We have a knowledge graph of the buildings.
We have the telemetry store that's getting something like 80 to 100 million messages per 24 hours.
And there's a state model there saying what's the state of the building portfolio, and this is across as I said, 2.7 million square meters.
Then on top there is also a real estate core API.

For apps that want to do something with this software, whether they be analytics or mobile apps or whatever, I want to set the temperature or I want to open the door or I want to do some analytics and do some set coins or whatever.
So this is a product that actually is running and works rather well and this is or the generic architectural so that we envisage that this will be used for.
Yeah, so we've also covered.

Doing this as I mentioned using this Eaton Company academic, who's there still in sort of a small scale trial there at about 25,000 square meters, so about 1/3 of this building if I recall correctly across two buildings.
Wilhelm, the residential there still prototyping.
There are not thrilled, trickier.
Space because there's a lot more GDP, are issues when you're dealing with residential apartments, of course.
We have Schneider Electric on board.
There are reasonably large.
You may have heard of them.
Electrical gadgets company and they have a system called structure where which is their building automation system.
They've open sourced connectors, so if you're running that system you can immediately hook into real estate core system accessory accessory accessions.
That's a consortium and company that deals with access control locks, digital locks, and so forth.
And a bunch of other enemies across northern Europe are working on this.
So what's going on going right now?
So the actuation semantics are, at the moment insufficient, and we're backporting them from this Eden platform.
They have actually gone beyond what the ontology allows us to do, and we're actually backporting that from this commercial vendor into the ontology to make it work.
And the API auto generation is ongoing.
We are also working now on generated or synthetic data points.
At present we only take the data points from the sensors.
But like oftentimes you want to aggregates or you want to do predictions or forecasts and you want to assign confidences and so forth.
So we're getting that reasonably soon as well.
And then key thing here alignment to existing ontologies.
And I think I'm out of time.
But if you want to ask me a question about why we're not using, those aren't aren't aligned to them properly yet.
The question and answering session would be suitable for that.
And finally, LEED certification module.
That's something that you can get your building certified per like this green building standard.
And that takes a lot of hours and a lot of time, and if we can help that process by data integration using this stuff, we're saving substantial man hours.
So that's also something that's ongoing.
I think that was all for now.
Thank you so much.
For your attention, I will be happy to take any questions if we have time for that.
